title-group.article-title: Balancing of flexible rotors without trial weights based on finite element modal analysis

article-meta.aff: The School of Power and Energy, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi’an, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Xiaofeng Li, The School of Power and Energy, Northwestern Polytechnical University, 127 West Youyi Road, Xi’an, 710072, People’s Republic of China Email: wilflxf@yahoo.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: With the continuous improvement of aviation engine performance, the engine rotor’s working speed is above the first critical speed, and some small engine rotor’s operating speed exceeds the second critical speed, thus most of the aircraft engine rotor is now flexible rotor. The primary goal of this research is to provide a new method without trial weights for flexible rotor balancing, which is based on the traditional modal balancing method and combines the dynamic characteristics of the rotor, such as the model shape, obtained by using finite element analysis software, the critical speed, the modal damping ratio, and so on. To demonstrate the validity and accuracy of the new method, two experiments are carried out. One is on a four-disk simply supported structure rotor experiment, which is balanced by using three balancing planes. After balancing the amplitude of the rotor through the first critical speed is reduced 80%. The other is on a turboshaft engine power turbine rotor which had been balanced quite well. The initial amplitude of the turboshaft engine power turbine rotor is 0.05 mm when it rotates at low speed, and the maximum amplitude is just 0.12 mm when it rotates at the first critical speed. After balancing the amplitude of the rotor through the first critical speed is reduced to 0.06 mm. The results of the experiments indicate that the new without trial weights method is a significant effective method for the flexible rotor dynamic balancing, and it will be widely used to balance the engine rotor.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The aero-engine rotor system is the most important part of the aero-engine. Engine fault often occurs because of excessive vibration of the rotor thereby causing severe engine vibration, which results in rotor parts being damaged because of deformation and overstress. In serious cases, the phenomenon, such as bearing locking, shaft transient breakage, appear due to the rotor bearing load being too large caused by the high vibration of the rotor. At the same time, the vibration of the rotor also directly affects the gap design between the rotor parts and the stator parts. Therefore, balancing a rotor which has eccentric mass distributions that generate large centrifugal forces and high levels of vibration is very important. Two different strategies have been adopted giving origin to the two families of balancing methods which were more widely used until the present: the influence coefficient methods and the modal balancing methods (Shih and Lee, 1997; Kreuzinger and Irretier, 2000; EI-Shafei, 2001; Zhou, 2002; Sèvea et al., 2003; Dong, 2007; Liu, 2007; Kang et al., 2008; Huang et al., 2009; Paolo et al., 2010). Both balancing methods require the measurement of the rotor’s original vibration, installing trial weights and measuring vibration after installing the trial weights, and perhaps a repetition of this process several times to balance the rotor. Many scholars begin to study the without trial weights balancing method. Several methods attempting rotor balancing without trial weights have been published in the past (Preciado and Bannister, 2000; Xu et al., 2000; Delgado and Bannister, 2002; EI-Shafei et al., 2004; Rodrigues et al., 2008). There are, however, no reports of the systematic application of these procedures to field balancing of large rotating machinery. This suggests that some practical difficulties have still to be solved. This paper describes a balancing method without trial weights, which only needs to measure the transient response and the steady-state response at the balancing speed of the rotor.

sec.title: 2. Detailed theory
sec.p:
It can be seen from the Figure 1, the eccentricity of the rotor after balancing consists of two parts, one is the continuous unbalance U→(z), which is a space curve, and the other is the discrete unbalance U→d, used to balance the rotor. According to the principle of mode superposition theorem, the eccentricity distribution of a flexible rotor can be expressed as a series of characteristic functions: (1){U→(z)=∑n=1∞C→nm(z)Φn(z)U→d(z)=∑n=1∞∑k=1KU→d(zk)Φn(zk)∫0lm(z)Φn2(z)dzm(z)Φn(z) (2)ɛ→(z)=U→(z)+U→d(z)m(z)=∑n=1∞(C→n+∑k=1KU→d(zk)Φn(zk)∫0lm(z)Φn2(z)dz)Φn(z) Where Φn(z) is the n th mode shape of the rotor, m(z) is the physical mass of the rotor, ɛ→(z) is the eccentricity distribution, and the elements C→nΦn(z) represent the initial modal components of eccentricity before balancing. Each one of these modal components excites a single mode of vibration. Figure 1.
The eccentricity distribution of the rotor after balancing.

It can be known by the rotor dynamics that the relationship between rotor vibration and the rotor eccentricity: (3){s→(z)=∑r=1∞ω2(ωr2-ω2)2+(2ζrωrω)2ɛ→r(z)ei(-αr)=∑r=1∞ω2(ωr2-ω2)2+(2ζrωrω)2 ×(C→r+∑k=1KU→d(zk)Φr(zk)∫0lm(z)Φr2(z)dz)Φr(z)ei(-αr)αr=arctan2ζrωrωωr2-ω2 Where s→(z) is the vibration of the rotor after balancing, ω is the rotation frequency, ωr is the r th natural frequency, ζr is the r th damping ratio, αr is the r th lag angle.

According to Figure 1, the reaction force of the left and right bearing can be calculated by the moment equilibrium principle: (4)F→R=ω2l[∫0lzm(z)s→(z)dz+∫0lzU→(z)dz+∑k=1KzkU→d(zk)]F→L=ω2l[∫0l(l-z)m(z)s→(z)dz+∫0l(l-z)U→(z)dz+∑k=1K(l-zk)U→d(zk)]F→R+F→L=ω2[∫0lm(z)s→(z)dz+∫0lU→(z)dz+∑k=1KU→d(zk)]}

In order to balance the rotor well, the reaction force of the rotor’s bearing must be zero, so the balance condition can be obtained from the equation (5): (6)C→r+∑k=1KU→d(zk)Φr(zk)∫0lm(z)Φr2(z)dz=0,r=1,2,…,∞∫0lU→(z)dz+∑k=1KU→d(zk)=0∫0lzU→(z)dz+∑k=1KzkU→d(zk)=0}
The rotor before balancing U→d=0. Considering equations (2) and (3), when ω=ωr, the equation (3) can be simplified to: (7)s→(z)=12ζrC→r(z)ei(-αr)Φr(z) So: (8)C→r=2ζrs→(z)Φr(z)ei(αr)
From the balance condition equation (6), the N planes modal balancing theory can be obtained: (9)∑k=1KU→d(zk)Φs(zk)={-C→r∫0lm(z)Φr2(z)dz,s=r0,s≠r(s=1,2,…n)

Substituting equation (8) into equation (9): (10)∑k=1KU→d(zk)Φs(zk)={-2ζrs→(z)Φr(z)ei(αr)∫0lm(z)Φr2(z)dz,s=r0,s≠r(s=1,2,…n) Where U→d(zk)=m→c(zk)·R(zk), m→c(zk) is the r th correction mass required at the balancing plane (zk), which forms part of the modal mass set required to compensate the unbalance in the r th mode. R(zk) is the radius at which the balancing mass is located at the balancing plane(zk). In order to make the equation (10) have a unique solution, the number of balancing planes should be equal to the number of vibration modes taken into consideration.

When the N + 2 planes modal balancing method should be considered, the set of correction masses can be obtained by solving following equations: (11){Ud(z1)+Ud(z2)+…+Ud(zk+2)=0∑k=1K+2Ud(zk)Φs(zk)={-2ζrs→(z)Φr(z)ei(αr)∫0lm(z)Φr2(z)dz,s=r0,s≠r(s=1,2,…n)z1Ud(z1)+z2Ud(z2)+…+zk+2Ud(zk+2)=0

sec.title: 3.1. Laboratory test - N + 2 planes modal balancing without trial weights
sec.p:
A four mass rotor system test rig is shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
The test rig layout and the arrangement of the detecting probes.

This four mass rotor system is supported by oil-impregnated sliding bearings and connected to the motor with a flexible coupling. The rotor shaft has a nominal diameter of 8 mm, an overall length of 450 mm. Four disks with a diameter of 76 mm are separated within the bearing span. Each disk has 72 screw holes, equally distributed on a circle with a radius of 30 mm, for adding trial weights. L1 = 32 mm, L2 = 48 mm, L3 = 48 mm, L4 = 44 mm and L5 = 42 mm. Displacement sensors are installed in the horizontal and vertical of the 2nd disk, 3rd disk and 4th disk.

Using the finite element analysis software-SAMCEF FOR ROTOR, the finite element model of the test rotor is established, and numerical simulation result shows that the first critical speed of the test rotor is 2513 r/min, while experimentally measured the test rotor’s first critical speed is 2500 r/min. The difference between the numerical simulation and the experiment is less than 0.01%, indicating that the mode shape of the test rotor obtained by numerical simulation is available. The modal analysis results of the test rotor are shown in Figure 3. The first natural frequency of the test rotor is 41.876 Hz, the second natural frequency is 153.443 Hz, and the third natural frequency is 323.167 Hz. Figure 3.
The mode shapes of the test rotor.

In the balancing procedure, the balancing speed is selected at 2320 r/min, and the 2nd disk, 3rd disk and 4th disk are selected as balancing planes to balance the first modal component of eccentricity. The D1 sensor is used to collect vibration data, which is substituted into the equation (11) for calculating the correction masses, and D2-D6 sensors are used to detect the balancing effect. Firstly the transient responses of the test rotor with original unbalance are measured to calculate the damping ratio, shown in Figure 4, the blue dotted line. Secondly the steady-state responses of the test rotor with original unbalance at the balancing speed is measured, and the vertical vibration vector at the 2nd disk is 0.2 mm at 20 degree. Lastly the vibration vector s→(zre) and the damping ratio ζr are substituted into the equation (11), which is solved to obtain the magnitude and phase of the correction masses required to balance the first modal component of unbalance. The results in correction masse for the first mode are 0.85e-3 kg at 17 degree on the 2nd disk, 1.66e-3 kg at 197 degree on the 3rd disk and 0.81e-3 kg at 17 degree on the 4th disk. After adding correction masses on the three disks according to the results, the vibration of the test rotor is measured again, and the resonant displacement at the 2th disk is from 0.72 mm down to 0.059 mm, reduced 87.5%. The balancing effect of this scheme is significant. Figure 4 shows the transient response of the test rotor before and after the balancing, Figure 5 shows the steady-state response of the test rotor before and after the balancing, and Figure 6 shows the axis orbit of the test rotor before and after the balancing. The resonance amplitudes at the three disks before and after the addition of the correction masses are shown in Tables 1 and 2, and the vibrations at the balancing speed are shown in Tables 3 and 4. Figure 4.
Transient response of the test rotor before and after the balancing.
Figure 5.
Steady-state response of the test rotor before and after the balancing.
Figure 6.
The axis orbit of the test rotor before and after the balancing.
Table 1.
The resonance amplitudes at the three disks for the horizontal direction
2nd disk 3rd disk 4th disk
Before the balancing/mm 0.72 0.73 0.65
After the balancing/mm 0.59 0.59 0.59
Initial bending/mm 0.56 0.56 0.56
Discrepancy(before)/mm 0.16 0.17 0.09
Discrepancy(after)/mm 0.03 0.03 0.03
Table 2.
The resonance amplitudes at the three disks for the vertical direction
2nd disk 3rd disk 4th disk
Before the balancing/mm 0.64 0.71 0.64
After the balancing/mm 0.47 0.54 0.53
Initial bending/mm 0.46 0.53 0.51
Discrepancy(before)/mm 0.18 0.18 0.13
Discrepancy(after)/mm 0.01 0.01 0.02
Table 3.
The vibration at the balancing speed for the horizontal direction
2nd disk 3rd disk 4th disk
Before the balancing(mm) 0.15 0.16 0.092
After the balancing(mm) 0.025 0.024 0.035
Decreasing amplitude 83.3% 85% 62%
Table 4.
The vibration at the balancing speed for the vertical direction
2nd disk 3rd disk 4th disk
Before the balancing(mm) 0.2 0.21 0.13
After the balancing(mm) 0.02 0.019 0.034
Decreasing amplitude 90% 91% 73.8%

It can be seen from Tables 1 and 2 that the maximum discrepancy between the resonance amplitudes and the initial bending at the three disks is 0.03 mm, and the minimum is just 0.01 mm after the balancing. Through comprehensive analysis of Tables 3 and 4, we can find that the vibration at the three disks is reduced 81% on average at the balancing speed after the addition of the correction masses. Considering that this rotor has very little damping, the vibration of the rotor at both critical speed and balancing speed are reduced considerably. This shows that the N + 2 planes modal balancing without trial weights method is effective and feasible.

sec.title: 3.2. Real-case study and field experiments - N planes modal balancing without trial weights
sec.p:
Figure 7 shows a turboshaft engine power turbine rotor structural diagram. Hollow power turbine shaft is the key component part for passing the power to the output shaft. It can be seen from Figure 7 that the power turbine shaft has slender, thin-walled and hollow structural characteristics. So, in order to transfer out of the two stage turbine power, the turbine shaft must not only be made of good materials to ensure the strength, but also be of high speed balanced to reduce the rotor’s vibration. Figure 7.
Turboshaft engine power turbine rotor structural diagram.

Using the SAMCEF FOR ROTOR finite element analysis software, a two-dimensional model of a power turbine rotor is established, as shown in Figure 8. In the model the reference axis for torsion test is equivalent to six concentrated mass points (A-F), and the blades are equivalent to two lumped mass points (G,H). The simulation results are shown in Figure 9. The first natural frequency of a power turbine rotor corresponding to the first order mode shape is 137 Hz; the second is 302 Hz; and the third is 658 Hz. Figure 8.
Two-dimensional finite element model of the power turbine rotor.
Figure 9.
The mode shapes of the power turbine rotor.

In order to verify the accuracy of numerical simulation results, experimental studies are carried out on the power turbine rotor. Figure 10 shows the sensor installation: D1, D2, and D3 are used to test the vertical vibration of the rotor, while D4 is used to test the horizontal vibration displacement. It can be seen from the mode shapes Figure 9 that the maximum amplitude of the rotor at the first mode shape is the position 20 mm right of the 1th boss, so the sensors (D1 and D4) are installed in the horizontal and vertical directions to monitor the maximum vibration of the rotor. Figure 11 shows the D1 sensor measured transient response of the power turbine rotor. By analyzing the transient response of the turbine rotor, it can be known that the first critical speed of the power turbine rotor is 8233 r/min, while the first natural frequency, obtained by numerical simulation, is 8220 r/min. The difference between them is less than 0.2%, so it shows that simulation and experiment are consistent. Figure 10.
Schematic diagram of power turbine rotor experimental test.
Figure 11.
Transient response of the power turbine rotor.

From the transient response in Figure 11, it can be seen that the maximum displacement of the rotor is very small, only 0.14 mm. This is because the power turbine rotor has been balanced using the influence coefficient method before using N planes without the trial weights modal balancing method. The aim is to improve the security of the new method used to balance the power turbine rotor, but this also increases the difficulty. Because the smaller the amplitude of the rotor, the more difficult it becomes to continue to reduce the displacement.

In the balancing procedure, D1 sensor is used to collect vibration data, which is induced into the equation (10) for calculating the correction mass, and D2-D4 sensors are used to detect the balancing effect. The balance speed is selected at 8200 r/min, and the 1th boss is used as the balance plane to balance the first modal component of eccentricity. At the balance speed, D1 sensor measured the vibration of the rotor is 0.095 mm, and phase is 210 degree, then the vibration s→(zre)and the damping ratio ζr obtained from the transient response data are substituted into the equation (10), which is solved to obtain the magnitude and phase of the correction mass required to balance the first modal component of unbalance. The result in correction mass for the first mode is 1.07e-3 kg at 20 degree on the 1th boss. After adding 0.7 e-3 kg correction mass on the 1st boss, measuring the amplitude of power turbine rotor again, the amplitude near the 1th boss is down to 0.045 mm. Compared to the vibration before balancing, the peak amplitude of the power turbine rotor is reduced 52.6%.

Figure 12 shows the transient response of the power turbine rotor for the vertical direction measured by D1, D2 and D3 sensors, before and after the attachment of the correction mass, and Figure 13 shows the steady-state response of the power turbine rotor before and after balancing. The steady-state responses at the balancing speed for the vertical direction before and after the addition of the correction masses are shown in Table 5. It can be seen from Table 5 that the decreasing amplitude at the 2th boss is the most, 65%, and the vibration of the power turbine rotor are decreased by 55% on average. This shows that the N planes modal balancing without trial weights method is also effective and feasible. Figure 12.
Transient response of the power turbine rotor before and after the balancing.
Figure 13.
Steady-state response of the power turbine rotor before and after the balancing.
Table 5.
Steady-state response at the balancing speed for the vertical direction
D1 sensor D2 sensor D3 sensor
Before the balancing(mm) 0.095 0.082 0.2
After the balancing(mm) 0.045 0.043 0.07
Decreasing amplitude 52.6% 47.6% 65%

sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, a modal balancing method without trial weights is presented, which only requires measuring the transient response and the steady-state response of the rotor at the balancing speed. The method is quite successful in balancing a flexible test rotor and a power turbine rotor. This shows that balancing without trial weights is not only a theoretical, but also a practical possibility. In this article the first critical speed of the rotor is balanced well by the new balancing method, then using the new method to balance the flexible rotor well at the second critical speed and even higher speeds can be studied further.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Aviation Industry Corporation of China.

def.p: the n th mode shape weight coefficient
the correction mass at balancing plane z = zk
the radius of the balancing plane
